quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 11 Quiz 10
quiz.subtitle: 11.10: De Moivre's Theorem
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Powers and roots of complex numbers

questions.question: If $z = 2(\cos 20^{\circ} + i \sin 20^{\circ})$, what is $z^3$?
questions.explanation: By De Moivre's Theorem, r³ = 2³ = 8, and the angle is 3 * 20° = 60°.

questions.question: How many distinct complex 4th roots does a number have?
questions.explanation: The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra implies that there are exactly n roots for any n-th degree operation.

questions.question: When finding the square roots of a complex number, how far apart are the two angles?
questions.explanation: Roots are always spaced evenly around the circle. For 2 roots, they are 360/2 = 180° apart.

questions.question: To find $(1 + i)^8$, it is easiest to:
options: Convert to trig form, then use De Moivre's Theorem.
questions.explanation: While multiplying works, De Moivre's turns it into a simple exponent and multiplication problem.

questions.question: Calculate $i^{10}$ using De Moivre's logic. (Note: $i$ is at 90° with $r=1$)
If $z^n = r^n \text{ cis }(n\theta)$, what is the modulus of the cube root of $z$?
questions.explanation: Finding a root is the same as raising to the 1/n power. The modulus becomes r^(1/n).

questions.question: In the root formula, what does 'k' represent?
options: The index of the root (0, 1, 2... n-1).
questions.explanation: k is the counter used to find each distinct root around the circle.

questions.question: Where do all the $n^{th}$ roots of a complex number lie when graphed?
options: On a circle centered at the origin.
On a straight line through the origin.
questions.explanation: Since all roots of a number have the same modulus (the n-th root of r), they all sit on a circle with that radius.

questions.question: True or False: De Moivre's Theorem only works for positive integer exponents.
questions.explanation: False. It works for negative integers, fractions, and even irrational exponents (though that's for a more advanced class!).

questions.question: Find the cube roots of 1 (the 'roots of unity'). How are they spaced?
questions.explanation: 360 / 3 = 120°. The roots of unity are always symmetrically distributed.

scoreMessages.90: De Moivre Deity! You've mastered the powers of the complex plane.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. Just remember to divide the angle when finding roots!
scoreMessages.50: Keep an eye on the spacing between roots (360/n).
scoreMessages.0: Review the power and root formulas for complex numbers in trig form.
